It's Friday and I am having "fun" - the geeky sort of work-related
fun, th=
at is.

I recently discovered Amazon.com's Mechanical Turk and created an
a=
ccount to see how the idea of AAI (Artificial Artificial Intelligence
- i.e=
. using human beings to work on tasks that computers generally
suck at, lik=
e pattern recognition) can be applied to testing
(creating, reviewing, impr=
oving, running tests, etc.)  

With Mechanical Turk, people get paid for do=
ing the tasks.  Payments
range from very small (e.g. $0.01 for deciding if =
a photo is a good)
to more substantial (e.g. $10.00 for transcribing a podc=
ast).

My first HIT (that stands for Human Intelligence Tasks - Amazon's
te=
rminology) is to ask someone to create a JUnit test that provides
100% stat=
ement and conditional coverage for a trivial Java class. I am
offering $1.1=
1 for each test that meets the coverage criteria.

NOTE:  I am not allowing=
 people to use JUnit Factory to automatically
generate the tests since we a=
lready know what those tests look like.

If you want to have fun with this,=
 I suggest you move quickly because
Amazon.com makes it rather cumbersome t=
o transfer funds to pay for
HITs, so I only have $10 available right now, a=
nd until I can put more
money into it, there are only a few hits I can pay =
for.

To "play" along just go to:

http://www.mturk.com/mturk/welcome

and =
search for hits containing the keyword: "junit".

Again, this is just for f=
un at this point...


Alberto

----------
http://www.junitfactory.com
Send =
it Java.  Get back JUnit.
100% free and 100% experimental.
